bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cesar Rodriguez Exposito, January 20, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Rodriguez Exposito that he has been asked to give an illustrated speech about the dedication of Camp Lazear for the Mayo Clinic. He would like to obtain two photographs de Castro laying Lazear's wreath.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cesar Rodriguez Exposito, January 20, 1953
div1.opener:
January 20, 1953
Mr. Cesar Rodriguez
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Rodroguez:
div1.p:
On arriving home from Cuba I plunged into the Christmas-New Year's acti-
vities, plus the necessity of preparing for a medical trip to California;
hence my delay in writing you to thank you most sincerely for your courtesy
in reading to the audience at the Dedication of Campamento Lazear my remarks.

I was very pleased with the whole affair and with the graciousness of my
Cuban friends. The many Americans who have learned of the dedication,
particularly the relatives of Major Reed and his associates, have also
been delighted to hear of the dedication. I have sent them a long letter
about it.

Some of these people would like photographs of various parts of the cere-
mony. Although Doctor Nogueira sent me some pictures, there are still some
missing. I have been asked to give an illustrated talk on the dedication
of Camp Lazear before the staff of the Mayo Clinic and I should like very
much to obtain through your help two pictures which appeared in AVANCE for
December 3. My recollection is that you are connected with that newspaper
but because I am not quite sure I am sending this to you through the
courtesy of Doctor Nogueira.

Would you ask your photographic colleagues on AVANCE to send me glossy
prints of the two following pictures:
1. AVANCE, December 3, 1952, page 6 - Dr. de Castro laying a wreath before
the medallion of Doctor Lazear.
2. AVANCE, December 3, 1952, page 6 - Boy Scouts and band.

I have a photograph of Dr. de Castro laying a wreath before one of the other
memorials but not before that of Doctor Lazear and I am anxious to send one
of these to his son and daughter. Could I therefore have 3 copies of the
first picture and one copy of the second? I don't know how much your photo-
graphers charge for newspaper photographs. In this country they usually charge
$1. I therefore enclose a check marked “not over five dollars,” please fill in
the amount.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
If I owe you more, I will be glad to send it.
